rue Berri / rue Cherrier[http://www.stm.info/English/metro/Sherbrooke.pdf Sherbrooke Station Neighbourhood Map] |}} '''Sherbrooke''' is a [[metro station|station]] on the [[Line 2 Orange (Montreal Metro)|Orange Line]] of the [[Montreal Metro]] [[Rapid transit|rapid transit system]], operated by the [[SociÃ©tÃ© de transport de MontrÃ©al]] (STM). It is located in [[The Plateau]] neighbourhood of the borough of [[Le Plateau-Mont-Royal]] in [[Montreal]], [[Quebec]], [[Canada]].[http://www.stm.info/English/metro/a-m10.htm Sherbrooke Metro Station] This station, near downtown, opened on October 14, 1966, as part of the original network of the metro. == Overview == [[File:Sherbrooke Montreal Metro2.jpg|thumb|left|Sherbrooke Metro station platform.]] The metro station, designed by Jean Dumontier and Crevier, Lemieux, Mercier et Caron, is a normal side-platform station, built in [[Tunnel#Cut-and-cover|open cut]] due to the difficulty of construction under Berri Street near the [[Sherbrooke Street]] [[overpass]]. It has a single [[Mezzanine (architecture)|mezzanine]] giving access to two entrances, one on either side of Berri Street, both integrated into buildings. The wall are decorated in straw-yellow brick, purple ceiling louvres and bulkhead walls, and orange highlights. == Architecture and art == [[Image:Mural at Sherbrooke Metro station.jpg|left|thumb|A mosaic mural at Sherbrooke station]] The station's main artwork is a mosaic, the only one in the metro, on the CÃ´te-Vertu platform. By [[Gabriel Bastien]] and [[Andrea Vau]], it depicts the achievements of the [[Saint-Jean-Baptiste Society]], whose headquarters are nearby. There are also two mural works by [[Mario Merola (artist)|Mario Merola]] in the accesses. ==Origin of the name== This station is named for [[Sherbrooke Street]]. Sir [[John Coape Sherbrooke]] (1764â1830) served as governor general of [[British North America]] 1816â1818.
